question: Takin' bets today, Red?
answer: Bear Catholic? Pope shit in the woods? Smokes or coin, bettor's choice.

question: Smokes. Put me down for two.
answer: High roller. Who's your horse?

question: Eyes front.
answer: This is Mr. Hadley, captain of the guard. I am Mr. Norton, the warden. You are sinners and scum, that's why they sent you to me. Rule number one

question: YOU EAT WHEN WE SAY YOU EAT! YOU PISS WHEN WE SAY YOU PISS! YOU SHIT WHEN WE SAY YOU SHIT! YOU SLEEP WHEN WE SAY YOU SLEEP! YOU MAGGOT- DICK MOTHERFUCKER!
answer: Any other questions? I believe in two things. Discipline and the Bible. Here, you'll receive both. Put your faith in the Lord. Your ass belongs to me. Welcome to Shawshank.

question: Say Tyrell, you pull infirmary duty this week? How's that winnin' horse of mine, anyway?
answer: What was his name?

question: What? What'd you say?
answer: I was wondering if anyone knew his name.

question: Hello. I'm Andy Dufresne.
answer: The wife-killin' banker.

question: How do you know that?
answer: I keep my ear to the ground. Why'd you do it?

question: I didn't, since you ask.
answer: Hell, you'll fit right in, then. Everyone's innocent in here, don't you know that? Heywood! What are you in for, boy?

question: What else have you heard?
answer: People say you're a cold fish. They say you think your shit smells sweeter than ordinary. That true?

question: What do you think?
answer: Ain't made up my mind yet.

question: I understand you're a man who knows how to get things.
answer: I'm known to locate certain things from time to time. They seem to fall into my hands. Maybe it's 'cause I'm Irish.

question: I wonder if you could get me a rock-hammer?
answer: What is it and why?

question: You make your customers' motives a part of your business?
answer: If you wanted a toothbrush, I wouldn't ask questions. I'd just quote a price. A toothbrush, see, is a non-lethal sort of object.

question: Fair enough. A rock-hammer is about eight or nine inches long. Looks like a miniature pickaxe, with a small sharp pick on one end, and a blunt hammerhead on the other. It's for rocks.
answer: Rocks. Quartz?

question: Quartz, sure. And look. Mica. Shale. Silted granite. There's some graded limestone, from when they cut this place out of the hill.
answer: So?

question: I'm a rockhound. At least I was, in my old life. I'd like to be again, on a limited scale.
answer: Yeah, that or maybe plant your toy in somebody's skull?

question: I have no enemies here.
answer: No? Just wait. Word gets around. The Sisters have taken a real shine to you, yes they have. Especially Bogs.

question: Tell me something. Would it help if I explained to them I'm not homosexual?
answer: Neither are they. You have to be human first. They don't qualify. Bull queers take by force, that's all they want or understand. I'd grow eyes in the back of my head if I were you.

question: Thanks for the advice.
answer: That comes free. But you understand my concern.

question: If there's trouble, I doubt a rock- hammer will do me any good.
answer: Then I guess you wanna escape. Tunnel under the wall maybe? I miss the joke. What's so funny?

question: You'll know when you see the rock- hammer.
answer: What's this item usually go for?

question: Seven dollars in any rock and gem shop.
answer: My standard mark-up's twenty percent, but we're talkin' about a special object. Risk goes up, price goes up. Call it ten bucks even.

question: Ten it is.
answer: I'll see what I can do. But it's a waste of money.

question: Oh?
answer: Folks who run this place love surprise inspections. They turn a blind eye to some things, but not a gadget like that. They'll find it, and you'll lose it. Mention my name, we'll never do business again. Not for a pair of shoelaces or a stick of gum.

question: I understand. Thank you, Mr...?
answer: Red. The name's Red.

question: Red. I'm Andy. Pleasure doing business with you.
answer: I could see why some of the boys took him for snobby. He had a quiet way about him, a walk and a talk that just wasn't normal around here. He strolled. like a man in a park without a care or worry. Like he had on an invisible coat that would shield him from this place. Yes, I think it would be fair to say I liked Andy from the start. He was a man who adapted fast. Years later, I found out he'd brought in quite a bit more than just ten dollars... When they check you into this hotel, one of the bellhops bends you over and looks up your works, just to make sure you're not carrying anything. But a truly determined man can get an object quite a ways up there. That's how Andy joined our happy little Shawshank family with more than five hundred dollars on his person. Determination. Andy was right. I finally got the joke. It would take a man about six hundred years to tunnel under the wall with one of these. Dufresne.

question: Because if you do trust her, there's no reason in the world you can't keep every cent of that money.
answer: You better start making sense.

question: If you want to keep that money, all of it, just give it to your wife. See, the IRS allows you a one-time- only gift to your spouse. It's good up to sixty thousand dollars.
answer: Naw, that ain't right! Tax free?

question: Tax free. IRS can't touch one cent.
answer: You're the smart banker what shot his wife. Why should I believe a smart banker like you? So's I can wind up in here with you?

question: It's perfectly legal. Go ask the IRS, they'll say the same thing. Actually, I feel silly telling you all this. I'm sure you would have investigated the matter yourself.
answer: Fuckin'-A. I don't need no smart wife-killin' banker to show me where the bear shit in the buckwheat.

question: Of course not. But you will need somebody to set up the tax-free gift, and that'll cost you. A lawyer, for example...
answer: Ambulance-chaaing, highway-robbing cocksuckers!

question: ...or come to think of it, I suppose I could set it up for you. That would save you some money. I'll write down the forms you need, you can pick them up, and I'll prepare them for your signature... nearly free of charge. I'd only ask three beers apiece for my co-workers, if that seems fair. I think a nan working outdoors feels more like a man if he can have a bottle of suds. That's only my opinion.
answer: What are you jimmies starin' at? Back to work, goddamn it!

question: No thanks. I gave up drinking.
answer: You could argue he'd done it to curry favor with the guards. Or maybe make a few friends among us cons. Me, I think he did it just to feel normal again...if only for a short while. King me.

question: Chess. Now there's a game of kings. Civilized...strategic...
answer: ...and totally fuckin' inexplicable. Hate that game.

question: Maybe you'll let me teach you someday. I've been thinking of getting a board together.
answer: You come to the right place. I'm the man who can get things.

question: We might do business on a board. But the pieces, I'd like to carve those myself. One side done in quartz... the opposing side in limestone.
answer: That'd take you years.

question: Years I've got. What I don't have are the rocks. Pickings here in the exercise yard are pretty slim.
answer: How's that rock-hammer workin' out anyway? Scratch your name on your wall yet?

question: Not yet. I suppose I should.
answer: Andy? I guess we're gettin' to be friends, ain't we?

question: I suppose we are.
answer: I ask a question? Why'd you do it?

question: I'm innocent, remember? Just like everybody else here. What are you in for, Red?
answer: Murder. Same as you.

question: Innocent?
answer: The only guilty man in Shawshank. Here's the good part. Bugs come out of the walls to get his ass.

question: I know. I've seen it three times this month already. Can we talk business?
answer: Sure. What do you want?

question: Rita Hayworth. Can you get her?
answer: No problem. Take a few weeks.

question: Weeks?
answer: Don't have her stuffed down my pants this very moment, sorry to say. Relax. What are you so nervous about? She's just a woman.

question: I know. I've seen it three times this month already. Can we talk business?
answer: Sure. What do you want?

question: Rita Hayworth. Can you get her?
answer: No problem. Take a few weeks.

question: Weeks?
answer: Don't have her stuffed down my pants this very moment, sorry to say. Relax. What are you so nervous about? She's just a woman.

question: Take a walk. I said fuck off. Ain't you gonna scream?
answer: They'd never hear me over that. Let's get this over with. Okay.

question: Now I'm gonna open my fly, and you're gonna swallow what I give you to swallow. And when you d mine, you gonna swallow Rooster's. You done broke his nose, so he ought to have somethin' to show for it.
answer: Anything you put in my mouth, you're going to lose.

question: You don't understand. You do that, I'll put all eight inches of this steel ii your ear.
answer: Okay. But you should know that sudden serious brain injury causes the victim to bite down. Hard. In fact, I understand the bite-reflex is so strong the victim's jaws have to be pried open with a crowbar.

question: Solitary. A week. Make sure he takes his Bible. Add another week for blasphemy. Let's try the second tier.
answer: Good evening.

question: I'm pleased to see you reading this. Any favorite passages?
answer: Watch ye therefore, for ye know not when the master of the house cometh.

question: Luke. Chapter 13, verse 35. I've always liked that one. But I prefer
answer: John. Chapter 8, verse 12.

question: My wife made that in church group.
answer: It's very pretty, sir.

question: You like working in the laundry?
answer: No, sir. Not especially.

question: Perhaps we can find something more befitting a man of your education.
answer: Hey, Jake. Where's Brooks?

question: Hey, Jake. Where's Brooks?
answer: Andy! Thought I heard you out here!

question: I've been reassigned to you.
answer: I know, they told me. Ain't that a kick in the ass? Come on in, I'll give you the dime tour. Here she is, the Shawshank Prison Library. Along this side, we got the National Geographics. That side, the Reader's Digest Condensed books. Bottom shelf there, some Louis L'Amours and Erle Stanley Gardners. Every night I pile the cart and make my rounds. I write down the names on this clipboard here. Well, that's it. Easy, peasy, Japanesey. Any questions?

question: Brooks? How long have you been librarian?
answer: Since 1912. Yuh, over 37 years.

question: In all that time, have you ever had an assistant?
answer: Never needed one. Not much to it, is there?

question: So why now? Why me?
answer: I dunno. Be nice to have some comp'ny down here for a change.

question: Not a dime. My budget's stretched thin as it is.
answer: I see. Perhaps I could write to the State Senate and request funds directly from them.

question: Far as them Republican boys in Augusta are concerned, there's only three ways to spend the taxpayer's hard-earned when it come to prisons. More walls. More bars. More guards.
answer: Still, I'd like to try, with your permission. I'll send a letter a week. They can't ignore me forever.

question: So Andy started writing a letter a week, just like he said. And just like Norton said, Andy got no answers. But still he kept on. The following April, Andy did tax returns for half the guards at Shawshank. Year after that, he did them all... including the warden's. Year after that, they rescheduled the start of the intramural season to coincide with tax season... The guards on the opposing teams all remembered to bring their W-2's.
answer: Moresby Prison issued you that gun, but you actually had to pay for it? See, that's all deductible. You get to write that off.

question: Yes sir, Andy was a regular H&R Block. In fact, he got so busy at tax time, he was allowed a staff.
answer: Say Red, could you hand me a stack of those 1040s?

question: I had Mr. Mozart to keep me company. Hardly felt the time at all.
answer: Oh, they let you tote that record player down there, huh? I could'a swore they confiscated that stuff.

question: The music was here...and here. That's the one thing they can't confiscate, not ever. That's the beauty of it. Haven't you ever felt that way about music, Red?
answer: Played a mean harmonica as a younger man. Lost my taste for it. Didn't make much sense on the inside.

question: Here's where it makes most sense. We need it so we don't forget.
answer: Forget?

question: That there are things in this world not carved out of gray stone. That there's a small place inside of us they can never lock away, and that place is called hope.
answer: Hope is a dangerous thing. Drive a man insane. It's got no place here. Better get used to the idea.

question: Like Brooks did?
answer: Yes sir, without a doubt. I can say I'm a changed man. No danger to society, that's the God's honest truth. Absolutely rehabilitated. Same old, same old. Thirty years. Jesus. When you say it like that...

question: You wonder where it went. I wonder where ten years went. Anniversary gift. Open it. Had to go through one of your competitors. Hope you don't mind. Wanted it to be a surprise.
answer: It's very pretty, Andy. Thank you.

question: You gonna play something?
answer: Not today. Andy was as good as his word. He kept writing to the State Senate. Two letters a week instead of one. In 1959, the folks up Augusta way finally clued in to the fact they couldn't buy him off with just a 200 dollar check. Appropriations Committee voted an annual payment of 500 dollars, just to shut him up. Those checks came once a year like clockwork. You'd be amazed how far Andy could stretch it. He made deals with book clubs, charity groups...he bought remaindered books by the pound...

question: Got his fingers in a lot of pies, from what I hear.
answer: What you hear isn't half of it. He's got scams you haven't dreamed of. Kickbacks on his kickbacks. There's a river of dirty money flowing through this place.

question: Money like that can be a problem. Sooner or later you gotta explain where it came from.
answer: That's where I come in. I channel it, funnel it, filter it...stocks, securities, tax free municipals... I send that money out into the big world. And when it comes back...

question: It's clean as a virgin's whistle?
answer: Cleaner. By the time Norton retires, I will have made him a millionaire.

question: Jesus. They ever catch on, he's gonna wind up wearing a number himself.
answer: I thought you had more faith in me than that.

question: I'm sure you're good, but all that paper leaves a trail. Anybody gets too curious -- FBI, IRS, whatever -- that trail's gonna lead to somebody.
answer: Sure it will. But not to me, and certainly not to the warden.

question: Who then?
answer: Peter Stevens.

question: Who?
answer: The silent, silent partner. He's the guilty one, your Honor. The man with the bank accounts. That's where the filtering process starts. They trace it back, all they're gonna find is him.

question: Yeah, okay, but who the hell is he?
answer: A phantom. An apparition. Second cousin to Harvey the Rabbit. I conjured him out of thin air. He doesn't exist...except on paper.

question: You can't just make a person up.
answer: Sure you can, if you know how the system works, and where the cracks are. It's amazing what you can accomplish by mail. Mr. Stevens has a birth certificate, social security card, driver's license. They ever track those accounts, they'll wind up chasing a figment of my imagination.

question: Jesus. Did I say you were good? You're Rembrandt.
answer: It's funny. On the outside, I was an honest man. Straight as an arrow. I had to come to prison to be a crook.

question: Does it ever bother you?
answer: I don't run the scams, Red, I just process the profits. That's a fine line, maybe. But I've also built that library, and used it to help a dozen guys get their high school diplomas. Why do you think the warden lets me do all that?

question: To keep you happy and doing the laundry. Money instead of sheets.
answer: I work cheap. That's the trade-off.

question: Well. Ain't this for shit?
answer: Tommy Williams came to Shawshank in 1965 on a two year stretch for B&E. Cops caught him sneakin' TV sets out the back door of a JC Penney. Young punk, Mr. Rock n' Roll, cocky as hell...

question: C'mon there, old boys! Movin' like molasses! Makin' me look bad!
answer: We liked him immediately.

question: I'm thinkin' maybe I should try for high school equivalency. Hear you helped some fellas with that.
answer: I don't waste time on losers, Tommy. That's a good start. If we do this, we do it all the way. One hundred percent. Nothing half-assed.

question: Thing is, see... ...I don't read all that good.
answer: Well. You've come to the right place then. ...and the lamplight o'er him streaming throws his shadow on the floor...and my soul from out that shadow that lies floating on the floor, shall be lifted nevermore! "

question: So this raven just sits there and won't go away?
answer: That's right.

question: Well?
answer: Well. It's for shit. Wasted a whole fuckin' year of my time with this bullshit!

question: May not be as bad as you think.
answer: It's worse! I didn't get a fuckin' thing right! Might as well be in Chinese!

question: We'll see how the score comes out.
answer: I'll tell you how the goddamn score comes out... Two points! Right there! There's your goddamn score! Goddamn cats crawlin' up trees, 5 times 5 is 25, fuck this place, fuck it! I feel bad. I let him down.

question: I'll tell you how the goddamn score comes out... Two points! Right there! There's your goddamn score! Goddamn cats crawlin' up trees, 5 times 5 is 25, fuck this place, fuck it! I feel bad. I let him down.
answer: That's crap, son. He's proud of you. Proud as a hen. We been friends a long time. I know him as good as anybody.

question: Smart fella, ain't he?
answer: Smart as they come. Used to be a banker on the outside.

question: What's he in for anyway?
answer: Murder.

question: The hell you say.
answer: You wouldn't think, lookin' at him. Caught his wife in bed with some golf pro. Greased 'em both. C'mon, boy, back to work...

question: Oh my God... 'Bout four years ago, I was in Thomaston on a 2 to 3 stretch. Stole a car. Dumbfuck thing to do. Few months left to go, I get a new cellmate in. Elmo Blatch. Big twitchy fucker. Crazy eyes. Kind of roomie you pray you don't get, know what I'm sayin'? 6 to 12 for armed burglary. Said he done hundreds of jobs. Hard to believe, high-strung as he was. Cut a loud fart, he'd go three feet in the air. Talked all the time, too, that's the other thing. Never shut up. Places he'd been, jobs he pulled, women he fucked. Even people he killed. People that gave him shit, that's how he put it. One night, like a joke, I say
answer: Andy?

question: Well. I have to say, that's the most amazing story I ever heard. What amazes me most is you were taken in by it.
answer: Sir?

question: It's obvious this fellow Williams is impressed with you. He hears your tale of woe and quite naturally wants to cheer you up. He's young, not terribly bright. Not surprising he didn't know what a state he'd put you in.
answer: I think he's telling the truth.

question: Let's say for a moment Blatch does exist. You think he'd just fall to his knees and cry, "Yes, I did it! I confess! By all means, please add a life term to my sentence!"
answer: It wouldn't matter. With Tommy's testimony, I can get a new trial.

question: That's assuming Blatch is even still there. Chances are excellent he'd be released by now. Excellent.
answer: They'd have his last known address. Names of relatives... Well it's a chance. isn't it? How can you be so obtuse?

question: What? What did you call me?
answer: Obtuse! Is it deliberate? The country club will have his old time cards! W-2s with his name on them!

question: Dufresne, if you want to indulge this fantasy, that's your business. Don't make it mine. This meeting's over.
answer: Look, if it's the squeeze, don't worry. I'd never say what goes on in here. I'd be just as indictable as you for laundering the money!

question: Don't you ever mention money to me again, you sorry son of a bitch! Not in this office, not anywhere! Get in here! Now!
answer: I was just trying to rest your mind at ease, that's all.

question: Solitary! A month!
answer: What's the matter with you? It's my chance to get out, don't you see that? It's my life! Don't you understand it's my life?

question: Since '47. Going on nineteen years. Board of Education.
answer: The son of a bitch mailed it.

question: Looks that way. You gonna open it or stick your thumb up your butt?
answer: Thumb up my butt sounds better. C'mon, just throw it away. Will you please? Just throw it away?

question: Well, shit.
answer: Out here? Warden?

question: Out here? Warden?
answer: Tommy, we've got a situation here. I think you can appreciate that.

question: Yes sir, I sure can.
answer: I tell you, son, this really came along and knocked my wind out. It's got me up nights, that's the truth. The right decision. Sometimes it's hard to figure out what that is. You understand? Think hard, Tommy. If I'm gonna move on this, there can't be the least little shred of doubt. I have to know if you what you told Dufresne was the truth.

question: Yes sir. Absolutely.
answer: Would you be willing to swear before a judge and jury...having placed your hand on the Good Book and taken an oath before Almighty God Himself?

question: Just gimme that chance.
answer: That's what I thought. Terrible thing. Man that young, less than a year to go, trying to escape. Broke Captain Hadley's heart to shoot him, truly it did.

question: My wife used to say I'm a hard man to know. Like a closed book. Complained about it all the time. She was beautiful. I loved her. But I guess I couldn't show it enough. I killed her, Red. I didn't pull the trigger. But I drove her away. That's why she died. Because of me, the way I am.
answer: That don't make you a murderer. Bad husband, maybe. Feel bad about it if you want. But you didn't pull the trigger.

question: No. I didn't. Someone else did, and I wound up here. Bad luck, I guess.
answer: Bad luck? Jesus.

question: It floats around. Has to land on somebody. Say a storm comes through. Some folks sit in their living rooms and enjoy the rain. The house next door gets torn out of the ground and smashed flat. It was my turn, that's all. I was in the path of the tornado. I just had no idea the storm would go on as long as it has. Think you'll ever get out of here?
answer: Sure. When I got a long white beard and about three marbles left rolling around upstairs.

question: Tell you where I'd go. Zihuatanejo.
answer: Zihuatanejo?

question: Mexico. Little place right on the Pacific. You know what the Mexicans say about the Pacific? They say it has no memory. That's where I'd like to finish out my life, Red. A warm place with no memory. Open a little hotel right on the beach. Buy some worthless old boat and fix it up like new. Take my guests out charter fishing. You know, a place like that, I'd need a man who can get things.
answer: Jesus, Andy. I couldn't hack it on the outside. Been in here too long. I'm an institutional man now. Like old Brooks Hatlen was.

question: You underestimate yourself.
answer: Bullshit. In here I'm the guy who can get it for you. Out there, all you need are Yellow Pages. I wouldn't know where to begin. Pacific Ocean? Hell. Like to scare me to death, somethin' that big.

question: Not me. I didn't shoot my wife and I didn't shoot her lover, and whatever mistakes I made I've paid for and then some. That hotel and that boat...I don't think it's too much to want. To look at the stars just after sunset. Touch the sand. Wade in the water. Feel free.
answer: Goddamn it, Andy, stop! Don't do that to yourself! Talking shitty pipedreams! Mexico's down there, and you're in here, and that's the way it is!

question: You're right. It's down there, and I'm in here. I guess it comes down to a simple choice, really. Get busy living or get busy dying.
answer: Andy?

question: Red, if you ever get out of here, do me a favor. There's this big hayfield up near Buxton. You know where Buxton is?
answer: Lots of hayfields there.

question: One in particular. Got a long rock wall with a big oak at the north end. Like something out of a Robert Frost poem. It's where I asked my
answer: What? What's buried there?

question: You'll just have to pry up that rock and see.
answer: I tell you, the man was talkin' crazy. I'm worried, I truly am.

question: Him. What do you mean "he just wasn't here?" Don't say that to me, Haig! Don't say that to me again!
answer: But sir! He wasn't! He isn't!

question: I can see that, Haig! You think I'm blind? Is that what you're saying? Am I blind, Haig?
answer: No sir!

question: You see Dufresne's name? I sure do! Right there, see? "Dufresne." He was in his cell at lights out! Stands to reason he'd still be here this morning! I want him found! Not tomorrow, not after breakfast! Now! Well?
answer: Well what?

question: I see you two all the time, you're thick as thieves, you are! He must'a said something!
answer: No sir, he didn't!

question: Lord! It's a miracle! Man up and vanished like a fart in the wind! Nothin' left but some damn rocks on the windowsill and that cupcake on the wall! Let's ask her! Maybe she knows! What say there, Fuzzy- Britches? Feel like talking? Guess not. Why should you be different? It's a conspiracy! That's what this is! It's one big damn conspiracy! And everyone's in on it! Including her!
answer: They got this skinny kid named Rory Tremont to go in the hole. He wasn't much in the brains department, but he possessed the one most important qualification for the job... ...he was willing to go. Probably thought he'd win a Bronze Star or something. It was his third day on the job.
